data.title: 1.3.0-insider breaks alt+left/right word skipping
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.3

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create/open an empty file
2. Type the text "Hello World"
3. While the cursor is at the end of the line, press Alt-Left
4. Expected behavior is that the cursor will jump to the left of the letter 'W'
5. Actual behavior is that the cursor just jumps to the left of the letter 'd'

data.title: Pressing <Tab> key adds tab to incorrect editor pane
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider, commit f8bb4ade94ba5c9401419d3ec1e12fbe8719e0c1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open two panes side-by-side
2. press tab in right-hand side (for example); notice that cursor doesn't move. Press tab a lot -- notice that left-hand pane starts scrolling horizontally. Focus left pane with ctrl-1 and see a large number of tabs appended to the current line there.

data.title: Grunt autodetection fails if local grunt is not installed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.x

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Workspace with grunt file but no local grunt installed
2. Global grunt cli installed
3. Configure task runner.

Observe: generate tasks.json with empty tasks array which hide the original problem of grunt not auto detecting.

data.title: Regression: ES6 & TypeScript "go to definition" jumps to import
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.5

I the past week (or two?) the "go to definition" feature for ES6 and TypeScript has changed from jumping to the original definition to jumping to the import at the top of the current file. That's the old broken behaviour which was reported in #263 (and despite that issue being open still, was actually fixed and has worked nicely for several months).

"Peek definition" also suffers from the same problem.

I've opened this as a new issue to report it as regression and not as a feature request 😄

data.title: Confusing message: No build tasks configured
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 10
- Node.js version 4.4.5 (LTS) version probably not critical...

Steps to Reproduce:
1.   Setup Node.js, then install the grunt-cli globally from a command prompt:   `npm install -G grunt-cli`
2.  Install source files from attached zip into an empty directory.  [junk.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/322685/junk.zip)
3.  Then from command prompt in that directory, install the dev dependencies with: `npm install`
4. Start VSCode with `code .`
5. From VSCode, Press **Ctrl+Alt+B**.   VSCode correctly says _No build task configured._  Choose "Configure Task Runner" and choose "Grunt" from the menu of templates.   Save it with **Ctrl+S**.
6. From VSCode, Press **Ctrl+Alt+B** again...

Observed:  
-  VSCode again says _No build task configured_, after we just created the suggested one... 
-  No output in tasks pane 
-  Pressing the "Configure Task Runner" button does nothing
-  Contents of URL referenced in the generated file are too complex to really help...

Expected:
- Should have run grunt, producing results in the output pane

data.title: Allow to use Ctrl P/N for up and down navigation in quick open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Invoke command palette
2. Begin typing a query i.e. ext
3. Attempt to move up/down the list with ctrl+p and ctrl+n

I installed the latest version of VS Code (1.2.1) on El Capitan. When I used the Atom (and ST2?) text editor and invoked the command palette I could cursor up/down the list using ctrl+p/ctrl+n.

For example, if I launch the command palette and search for extension I get the following list:

```
Extensions: Install Extension
Extensions: Show Extension Recommendations
Extensions: Show Installed Extensions
Extensions: Show Outdated Extensions
```

If I want to get to 'Show Installed Extensions' I would press ctrl+n twice in Atom. When I try doing this with VS Code nothing happens. In looking at the Default Keyboard Shortcuts there are:

```
{ "key": "ctrl+p", "command": "cursorUp", "when": "editorTextFocus" },
{ "key": "ctrl+n", "command": "cursorDown", "when": "editorTextFocus" },
```

data.title: Nested Launch Configurations

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Would it be possible to have VS Code scan for any child `.vscode` folders or other files named `launch.json` and include those in the debug configuration available?  I have a git project where there are many sub-modules and I would like to have the debug configuration contained in each sub-module.

I am happy to contribute this myself if someone could point me in the right direction.
(I think looking for all files named `launch.json` would be easiest/cleanest)

data.title: Can't install dependencies with npm >= 3.9

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I was thinking of making a pull request, and tried checking out and building the vscode source, but I get the error `MSVSProject' object has no attribute 'iteritems'` when I try to run `scripts\npm install`. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8770194/16179512/4f48970e-3668-11e6-905b-fa96240cb9d0.png)

I followed the instructions [How to run from Source](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#build-and-run-from-source), and tried out the instructions [Compiling native addon modules](https://github.com/Microsoft/nodejs-guidelines/blob/master/windows-environment.md#compiling-native-addon-modules) when that didn't work. I can get e.g. bson and node-sass to install and compile native code via node-gyp without issues.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8770194/16179521/a5e12310-3668-11e6-8bf0-7d8c84a1f447.png)

I can't seem to figure out what's causing this issue. Any help is greatly appreciated.

System info:
Windows 10
npm@3.9.6
node@6.2.2
git 2.9.0.windows.1

3. Ran code.exe followed by a filename, and the file spawned a new Code.exe window.

data.title: "zoom in" vscode key mapping needs to be [Ctrl +] instead of [Ctrl =]
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. start a vscode edit session
2. use F1 with search term "zoom"

You see a mapping of [Crtl =] to zoom in.

It would be more consistent if this was mapped to [Ctrl +]
For example, zoom out is mapped to [Ctrl -]

Most keyboards have + and = on the same key-cap, but not all.

data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.3.0 Insiders 2016-06-17T05:01:41.413Z - OS Version: OS X 10.11.5（15F34） If there is a space in the file name of the image file can not be displayed in the Markdown preview. It can be displayed if you use the HTML img tag ``` * NG: `![alt](http://link)` ![alt](/Users/satokaz/Gits/advanced-vscode/markdown-it-extension/images/test 1.png) * OK: HTML img tag ``` Steps to Reproduce: 1. If there are spaces in the file name or folder name 2. write `![alt](http://link)` and Markdown preview

data.title: No auto-suggest for React components' props interface
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.5
- TypeScript versions: 1.8.10 and 1.9.0-dev

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Declare an interface to define a React component's props.
2. There's no suggestion for the interface while declaring the component's `props` generic.
3. The interface name _is_ available for auto-complete inside the component body itself and works as expected.
4. A similarly declared interface for the state _is_ suggested.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/390540/16175849/ef14c4e6-3619-11e6-82ff-7a1be9530b2d.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/390540/16175855/0f474fa4-361a-11e6-927e-e72813d67162.png)

data.title: Support to use groups over position in IEditorGroupService
data.body: We should retire the concept of `Position` and use stacks model concepts instead.

data.title: Add 'vscode' as a keyword in the .desktop file
data.body:
I find myself always typing vscode when searching for vs code in gnome 3, however being that there is no word vscode in the desktop file the search always comes up empty, and I realise that i have to type in code not vscode.
This small addition makes it searchable using term vscode.

data.title: Debugger + NodeJS + Error Stack + SourceMaps (TypeScript)

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
It would be awesome if debugger would use source maps when outputting stack for an Error. 

Right now it will output:

```
[Error]
   {
     stack: 'TypeError: Cannot read property \'config\' of null\n 
   at null.<anonymous> (..../build/handlers/test.js:57:50) ....
```

and you can click that file name to jump to file (but it jumps to built js file - not source typescript file)

ideally if it showed: 

```
     stack: 'TypeError: Cannot read property \'config\' of null\n 
   at null.<anonymous> (..../src/handlers/test.ts:68:46) ....

```

and you could click it to go to the TypeScript source file and proper location.

Thanks

data.title: Tabs
data.body:
- [x] win - @alexandrudima 
- [x] mac - @isidorn 
- [x] linux - @Tyriar 

Enable tabs by setting the `workbench.editor.showTabs` setting to `true`. Verify:
- you see tabs for each opened editor and the active tab is always revealed and stands out from others
- you can interact with a tab from its context menu
- you can move tabs around with drag and drop
- when not all tabs can fit the available space you can scroll with the mouse to reveal all and the overflow action in the right corner enables and shows all opened tabs in a list
- dirty editors always show their indicator even when the tab is not active
- tabs are being reused as long as the editor inside is a preview editor (showing in italics)
- you can change where editors open by configuring `workbench.editor.openPositioning`
- you can disable preview editors by changing `workbench.editor.enablePreview` or `workbench.editor.enablePreviewFromQuickOpen`
- verify keyboard accessibility on tabs
- verify screen reader on tabs
- verify tabs are looking good in all themes including high contrast theme
